page.title: 01Principal Features
page.content: The county of Buckinghamshire is in the south-east of England.The 12 square kilometres we are covering are in the south-east corner of Buckinghamshire. Through Buckinghamshire runs a range of hills called the Chilterns which have gentle slopes.This range of hills is divided by the Chess Valley.Through the Chess Valley runs the River Chess, which flows into the Bury Pond and carries on through Chesham. Chesham is at the head of the five valleys.The height ranges from 105 to 175 metres. There is woodland throughout the area and the north and west is mainly used for agricultural purposes. In the east there is the town of Chesham and Lowndes Park,with Scottowes Pond.St.Mary's church is the oldest building in Chesham and sticks out on the skyline.Chartridge is a quiet village surrounded by countryside.
